abstract.p: Michelle Leake letter disputes Matt Richtel's July 9 contention that societal forces push college students toward using Napster, which she sees as mere part of churn in business cycle/

block.p: Re ''A Binge on Music at State U.'' (Backslash, July 9) in which Matt Richtel talked with college students who contended that societal forces had pushed them toward using Napster, the controversial free Internet service that allows computer users to share digital music files:

Re ''A Binge on Music at State U.'' (Backslash, July 9) in which Matt Richtel talked with college students who contended that societal forces had pushed them toward using Napster, the controversial free Internet service that allows computer users to share digital music files:

Mr. Richtel would have us believe that Napster users are complete bubbleheads with no sense of the larger business picture, and how Napster fits into that picture. As an avid ''Napsterist,'' I would challenge that the Recording Industry Association of America and its affiliated record labels are just looking to take the offensive and give Napster its comeuppance for perceived copyright infringement.

The record industry is not acting rationally, but instead out of animus and spite. Napster is a perfect manifestation of what the economist Joseph Schumpeter deemed ''creative destruction''; that is, supplanting certain industries with innovation and improved technology. In other words, Napster is just a part of the churn in the business cycle.
